summary:
Me: *hasn't watched spider-verse yet* 
Me, also: I should make a spidersona
But yeah!! They come from a universe where...
body:
Me: *hasn’t watched spider-verse yet*

Me, also: I should make a spidersona

But yeah!! They come from a universe where radioactive spiders are considered pests lmao

they are on a Team of Fellow Chaotic Good Students, n have a sewer hangout™

Some powers are:

  • Organic webbing cause thats the good stuff
  • Ignoring gravity(its just wall climbing)
  • Hissing and clicking Intimidatingly
  • Smacking people with a giant pencil they found one day

Yeah! Thats them. Spighty (Spider Nighty)

summary: ... That wasn’t actually that bad. Like, turning Hogbgoblin into a catholic fanatic, after he literally went ahead and offered...
body:
… That wasn’t actually that bad. Like, turning Hogbgoblin into a catholic fanatic, after he literally went ahead and offered his soul to a demon to get his goblin powers, wasn’t something I liked, especially since McFarlane didn’t even bother to show his descent into madness or any catalyst that might have made it take a religious turn. I mean, last time someone made a reference to his appearance in Spec, he acted like he didn’t understand what people were talking about. While the change wasn’t impossible and, considering the demonic nature of his powers and how he most likely sold his soul for them (he offered it and the demon laughed at him and said it wasn’t worth shit, but he did give him his powers, so he might have accepted anyway or he might have bestowed them because he entertained him and he knew they would bring Hobgoblin grief), you could even go ahead and say they drove him mad without even needing to find a reason, but this is an example of a situation where you shouldn’t leave things implicit or up to the readers’ imagination, because it’s just bad/lazy writing. Which, considering who wrote the story, isn’t really surprising. 

Don’t get me wrong, I’ve heard good things of McFarlane’s stories, so he’ll probably get better as I go along, but he’s just starting out and, to be honest, I might be biased against him, because the fact that his very first attempt at a story was a KLH wannabe (tremendously ambitious and a bad idea both because he set himself up to be compared to one of the greatest Spider-Man stories out there, not only because of the plot itself but also for the sheer skill with which it was presented, while he himself was a complete amateur) and his own admission in the text page in Spider-Man #1 that he basically wanted to get his own mag to practice his writing and get to draw whatever he wanted didn’t really endear him to me, even if I can see that he honestly just wanted to improve his skills and maybe make a tribute to a story he liked (then again, he also admitted he’d come up with the story mostly by just going “so, every other rogue is in use, but this guy had the idea to use Calypso, so I’ll use her” and the idea to do a KLH tribute might have come more from that than any love for the story). Going head first into making a sequel for KLH, especially trying to recreate a style that wasn’t universally liked even when it was done right and not by someone who was just starting out his writing career, was just not the way to go about it. And that’s just the writing skills part of it. (Also I don’t like his art don’t @ me.) Although I did like the juxtaposition of Peter’s past, his triumphant resurface from his grave, with his present, the reality of, as Calypso so cruelly and mockingly put it, him “punching at shadows” because he was caught in the flashback of that moment.

greatrunner | 30 | Sagittarius | Writer. | Professional Heel. | Formerly everyleaffallstoosoon and vemeer-mark-iv | banner: ironmacn

Hello, strange wanderer of the tumblrsphere of danger. This is a blogsphere for my personal likes and interests. If you're interested in what I happen to be interested in, check out my archive, tags and navigation. This is not a spoiler free zone, I usually don't mark spoilers. This blog contains blood, gore and body horror. Basically it contains content that isn’t for thirteen and under audiences, so please don’t follow me if you aren’t 18+. Thanks for visiting, tho.

summary: Spider-Man: The Animated Series on DVD... in the United Kingdom,  Anyway So, much like NBC’s Journeyman, all five seasons...
caption:
Spider-Man: The Animated Series on DVD… in the United Kingdom,  Anyway

So, much like NBC’s Journeyman, all five seasons of Spider-Man: The Animated Series actually got a complete, full on DVD release in the United Kingdom.

Spider-Man: The Animated Series was actually released on DVD, with all 65 episodes, almost eight or nine years ago, 2009, in the United Kingdom. 

The DVDs are apparently still fairly obtainable in the UK, and a lot of older Marvel cartoons like Silver Surfer, Fantastic Four, The Incredible Hulk, Iron Man, and even Spider-Man Unlimited (the hijacked Spider-Man 2099 series) got releases like this overseas as well.

I’m trying my holy damnedest not to scream rn.

summary:
Spoilers for Into The Spiderverse
Ok so I've heard a lot about Peni in Into the Spiderverse. I am not familiar with her original...
body:
Spoilers for Into The Spiderverse

Ok so I’ve heard a lot about Peni in Into the Spiderverse. I am not familiar with her original comics so I can’t really say much about whether her art style in the movie was offensive, or inaccurate, or whatever. But the bit at the end of the film where her robot is destroyed felt a little cheap, like before that moment the film made no attempt to explore her character beyond the brief rundown of her backstory (understandable her being a background character to Miles and Peter) and it felt weird that the filmmakers attempted to get audiences to sympathize with her in that moment and in that way when doing so had no greater effect on the plot or character development. Like it just felt unnecessary.

reblog.comment:
